AFG.main:
Assistance needs due to armed conflict and frequent natural disasters include food, healthcare, and protection.? With the increase in the number of people internally displaced by conflict and the influx of returnees from Pakistan and Iran in the year 2016, shelter and WASH needs have increased significantly. 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance.?However, the high level of insecurity constrains access.?

INFORM measures Afghanistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7.8/10. Afghanistan’s hazard is of particular concern, at 8.8/10.?
AFG.latest_developments_past:
08/03: 38 killed and more than 70 injured in an IS attack on Sardar Daud Khan Hospital, a health facility for wounded army soldiers in Kabul.??
 
07/03: Pakistan opened the Torkham and Chaman border crossings with Afghanistan for two days so that visa holders stranded on the two sides can return to their countries. The borders have been closed for 18 days. Pakistan plans on closing the borders again on Thursday 9 March.?
 
01-03/03: Afghan forces recaptured Tala Barfak district, Baghlan province, after the district was captured by the Taliban on 1 March following days of heavy fighting between the Taliban and Afghan forces.??
 
01/03: Coordinated suicide attacks by the Taliban killed 22 people and injured 120 others.?
AFG.latest_developments_upcoming:
UNHCR suspended facilitated returns during the winter season from 1 November, 2016 to 28 February, 2017.?Closure of Afghan-Pakistani border crossings has put a hold on the resumption of facilitated returns.

Pakistan has extended the deadline for registered Afghan refugees to leave the country to the end of the year 2017.

There is a likelihood for average to above-average precipitation during the remainder of the wet season through May.?

By June 2017, the number of acutely food insecure people will likely decrease seasonally from a peak in late winter/early spring. ?

AGO.main:
The El Niño-induced drought experienced throughout 2016 has impacted the food security, nutrition and health needs of 1.2 million people in Angola, particularly in the southern provinces.?

Severe acute malnutrition rates are estimated above 4% in the three most affected provinces, with increasing reports of waterborne diseases, malaria and lack of access to safe water. 90% of the estimated affected population live in rural areas, far from health centres, schools and markets.? 

INFORM measures Angola’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 7/10.?
AGO.latest_developments_upcoming: 31/08: General elections in Angola.?

BDI.main:
Political instability has crippled Burundi’s economy and driven massive displacement, as populations continue to flee violence carried out by both the government and opposition, and their respective supporters. Deteriorating socioeconomic conditions are driving humanitarian needs for basic health and education services, as well as food, nutrition, and livelihoods support? Over 368,000 people have fled political violence to neighbouring countries since April 2015. ? By the end of 2017, it is estimated this figure will exceed 524,000. ?

Burundi, which scores 6.3/10 on the INFORM index, which is considered to be very high.?
BDI.latest_developments_past:
02/03: 1.5 million Burundians are estimated to be severely food insecure. ? 

01/03: There were at least 906,000 cases of Malaria and 383 deaths in January this year, over 230,000 cases more than the monthly average of 2016. ?

BEN.main: Benin suffered a Lassa fever outbreak in early 2016. For details, see the Special Reports tab.

BFA.main: Flooding in August 2015 affected over 24,000 people in Burkina Faso. ACAPS Briefing Note on the crisis can be found under Special Reports.

BGD.main:
The influx of Rohingya refugees from Myanmar is reported on in an ACAPS briefing note of January 2017.? This report, along with reports of floods in August 2016 are available in the Special Reports tab of this window.

The country is recovering from flooding in July and August, and was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since the beginning of November. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Bangladesh on a weekly basis, due to its high underlying vulnerability and frequency of natural disasters.

BIH.main: Bosnia and Herzegovina was affected by flooding in May 2014. For more information, see our Briefing Note.

BOL.main: Bolivia has been facing a worsening drought situation since October 2015. In August 2016, ACAPS produced a Briefing Note with an overview of current needs in the country.

BRA.main: When Zika virus hit Latin America and the Caribbean in 2015, Brazil was most affected , reporting over a million cases by early February 2016. ACAPS' Briefing Note on the epidemic is available under Special Reports.

CAF.main:
Conflict has resulted in displacement, targeted killings along communal lines, and human rights abuses. Protection, humanitarian access, and food security are priority needs, as continued violence, looting, and displacement cause further deterioration of an already dire humanitarian situation across the country. Needs continue to exceed available resources, and delivery of aid is expected to decline because funding remains low. 

INFORM measures CAR's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.4/10. CAR's vulnerability is of particular concern.?
CAF.latest_developments_past:
28/02: 11,110 cases of sexual and gender-based violence were recorded in 2016, including 2,313 cases of sexual violence.?

28/02: In Bangui, in some neighboorhood, returning IDPs have no local access to water, and wells have fallen into disrepair. They are forced to collect water in PK5 district, which is insecure.?

23/02: 402,240 IDPs are registered across the country. This is 4.5% fewer than in October 2016, due to the closure of IDP camps in Bangui.More than 60% live in host communities.??

CHN.main:
A peak in air pollution in December 2016 impacted millions of people across northeast and central China, see our Briefing Note.

Longtoushan township in Ludian county, Yunnan province, was hit by an earthquare in August 2014. 230,000 people were relocated. For details on the immediate impact, see ACAPS Special Reports.

CIV.main:
Côte d’Ivoire is recovering from more than a decade of violent conflict, and the displaced are slowly beginning to return home. The most pressing issue is food insecurity: 76,000 people are are in need of assistance. A high rate of statelessness is a major protection concern and limits access to livelihoods.?? An estimated 700,000 people living in the country do not have any documented nationality.?

Economic improvements and a reduction in food insecurity point to an improving situation in Côte d’Ivoire. Although ranked as a Situation of Concern in the Global Emergency Overview until June 2016, Côte d’Ivoire is now prioritised as a situation of No Severity. ACAPS continues to monitor Côte d’Ivoire on a weekly basis, but updates are no longer regularly posted. It ranks 4.5 on the INFORM Risk Index.?

CMR.main:
Almost 10% of the population is in need of humanitarian assistance, primarily in Far North, North, Adamaoua, and East regions. Conflict in both Nigeria and CAR has led to displacement of refugees to Cameroon. Boko Haram attacks in the Far North region have become much less frequent than in the beginning of 2016. Needs remain high in Minawao camp, which hosts more than 60,000 refugees. ?

INFORM considers that the risk of humanitarian crisis varies widely, from very high in the Far North to very low in western areas of the country. Nationally, the risk is 6.2/10 – a vast increase from 4.6 last year. Hazard and exposure risk stands at 6.8, and lack of coping capacity at 6/10. ?
CMR.latest_developments_past: 07/03: 14 suspected cases of cholera were reported in the Centre and Littoral regions for the first time in 2017. Four test have been negative. ?

COD.main:
A complex emergency has persisted in DRC for more than 20 years. Conflict is between foreign, self-defence, and other armed groups, and mainly impacting the eastern provinces. Although the security situation has improved slightly since 2013, conflict continues. Access remains volatile in the east, and lack of infrastructure is a general problem across the country. Fighting in insecurity is currently mostly affecting populations in Sud- and Nord-Kivu, Ituri, Tanganyika, and Haut-Katanga provinces. Health is a priority due to recurrent measles, cholera, and malaria outbreaks, and protection concerns are high.

A presidential election is due in 2017, and it has been agreed that President Kabila, whose term limit ended in December 2016, will then step down. At least 50 people died in election-related violence in 2016. 

INFORM measures DRC's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 8/10 as well as vulnerability at 7/10.?
COD.latest_developments_past:
04/03: Renewed Clashes between supporters of Bundu Dia Mayala (BDM) and security forces in Kinshasa, have resulted in at least four deaths.?

02/03: Over 30 houses were destroyed by heavy rains in Ingbokolo, Aru territory (Ituri).?

25/01–01/03: Over 20 people were killed as a result of the FARDC offensive against ex-M23 in Nord-Kivu.?
COD.latest_developments_upcoming: Tension and violence are increasing in Katanga area because of the delay in the elections. There are concerns that a crisis, similar to the war of late 1990s, which followed the overthrowing of Mobutu, could take place. ?

COL.main:
After five decades of armed violence, the peace deal with the FARC has not put an end to violence, as other armed groups battle for territory that the FARC is in the process of leaving. Forced displacement and landmine contamination are major concerns. In rural communities, armed group activity restricts movement and limits access to basic health services, as well as access to crops, and labour markets, especially in the Pacific region.

Colombia also experiences frequent natural disasters, particularly tropical storms and heavy rains on the Pacific coast.

INFORM measures Colombia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 at 5.4/10. Hazard and exposure as well as vulnerability are a particular concern, at 6.8/10 and 5.8/10. ?
COL.latest_developments_past: 04-06/03: Hundreds of people were displaced in the Baudo region of Chocó during clashes between Urabeños and the ELN.?

DJI.main:
Recurrent and severe droughts over the past two decades have led to a significant deterioration in Djibouti’s humanitarian situation. As a result, the population’s coping capacities have steadily been eroded causing rural to urban migration, which has left many households unable to generate sufficient income to meet basic needs.

The presence of migrants and refugees has created additional pressure on the state’s limited capacity. There has been an influx of refugees from Yemen since the escalation of conflict in March 2015. Additionally, the country hosts long-term Somali, Ethiopian, and Eritrean refugees, as well as Djiboutian returnees from Yemen, and transiting migrants. 

INFORM measures Djibouti’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 to be high, at 5.3/10 up from 4.4/10 in 2016. Lack of coping capacity is of concern, at 6.5/10.? Humanitarian needs are severely increasing as refugee camps are overwhelmed with refugees and migrants.

ECU.main:
On 16 April 2016, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck west of Ecuador’s northern coast. The earthquake left 350,000 people in need of assistance, killed at least 662 people and injured 4,605.? 

INFORM measures Ecuador's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.3/10.? 

By mid-August, Ecuador no longer met the criteria to appear in the Global Emergency Overview. ACAPS continues to monitor the country on a weekly basis, but updates have stopped.
ECU.latest_developments_past: An ACAPS briefing note on the earthquake in Ecuador in April 2016 is available under the Special Reports tab.

EGY.main: Egypt hosts some 120,000 Syrian refugees, and has been covered in a number of reports by ACAPS on the Syria crisis. See Special Reports.

ERI.main:
The Eritrean government severely restricts the access of humanitarian actors inside the country. Very little is known about humanitarian needs: UNICEF estimates that the total affected population is 1.5 million.? UN operations have been restricted to health, water supply and sanitation. An average of 5,000 Eritreans per month are thought to flee the country. Much of the country is affected by recurrent drought, which has been particularly severe over the past year as a result of El Niño.

INFORM measures Eritrea's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be 5.4/10. Eritrea's vulnerability is measured at 4.8/10.

ETH.main:
A state of emergency was declared on 8 October following large-scale anti-government protests. The protests started in November 2015, and Ethiopian government forces have killed at least 800 demonstrators in 2016. ?

Consecutive, below-average rainy season yields for the Gu (from March to May) and Deyr (October to December) seasons have caused severe drought across northern, eastern, and central Ethiopia.  ? This is leading to high levels of food insecurity, particularly in Afar, in Sitti zone of Somali region, and parts of Amhara, Oromia, and SNNPR. Malnutrition has increased significantly. ? Below-average rainfall is projected for the Belg season, which will affect the drought in the southern and south-eastern parts of the country.  ?

Hosting over 781,000 refugees from neighbouring countries, including over 320,000 from South Sudan, the majority of Ethiopia’s refugee camps have reached full capacity. Overcrowding, malnutrition, and critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid are of concern. Most refugees have been in protracted displacement, but remain in need of assistance.

INFORM measures Ethiopia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.6/10. ?
ETH.latest_developments_past:
07/03: Assessments pertaining to January estimate that GAM and SAM levels in the heavily drought impacted Somali region were above emergency threshold, at 16.4% and 2.7% respectively. ? 

28/02: 44,000 households in Gambella, Oromia, and Somali regions have requested shelter assistance since the beginning of the year. ? 

28/02: At least 228,000 children have been out of school as a result of the drought in Oromia and Somali regions. 578 schools (437 in Somali region and 141 in Oromia) have been closed since November 2016. ?
ETH.latest_developments_upcoming: Drought conditions are expected to persist in southern Afar, east and central Oromia, northeastern SSNPR and virtually all of Somali region until May. Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food security outcomes are anticipated in these areas from February until May?

FJI.main: As a result of TC Winston as well as subsequent flooding, Fiji was ranked as a Situation of Concern in the Global Emergency Overview from February to April 2016. Now prioritised as a situation of No Severity, ACAPS continues to monitor Fiji on a weekly basis, but updates are no longer regularly posted. Fiji ranks 3.2 on the INFORM Risk Index.?

GIN.main:
Humanitarian needs in Guinea spiked in 2014 and 2015, when the Ebola epidemic caused a severe crisis throughout the country.

Guinea's baseline indicators (see Country Profile) provide an insight into the country's vulnerability to crisis. Reports relating to the Ebola epidemic are under Special Reports.

GMB.main:
Over 230,000 people are food insecure, including 35,000 in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food insecurity. ? The North Bank, Upper River, and West Coast regions are particularly affected. More than 10,000 children under five are severely malnourished. Food insecurity is due to crop failure / poor harvest, rising food prices, and loss of livelihoods as a result of numerous disasters over the last few years such as drought and floods.

Adama Barrow became President of the Gambia on 19 January. Former President Yahya Jammeh, who had been in power for over 22 years, stepped down on 21 January. Despite initially accepting the result, Jammeh disputed Adama Barrow’s victory. Thousands of people fled to Senegal in early January 2017, due to the political instability. The pre-election period saw unprecedented anti-government protests and dozens of activists wounded in clashes with police.

INFORM measures Gambia’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very low, at 3.6/10. Gambia’s vulnerability is of concern, at 5.1/10. ?

GRC.main: Greece has been the landing-point for hundreds of thousands of people seeking asylum in Europe. ACAPS has produced a number of reports covering the humanitarian needs of migrants and refugees: see the Special Reports tab. For more information, see also the theme page.

GTM.main:
A report on the Northern Triangle from December 2016, on the zika virus in February 2016, and the drought in September 2015 is available in the Special Reports tab of this window. 

Guatemala suffered from drought from 2015- 2016, with over 900,000 people classified as food insecure. This, along with gang-related protection concerns made Guatemala a Situation of Concern in ACAPS' Global Emergency Overview. However, drought effects subsided in the second half of 2016, with only 110,000 classified as food insecure in December 2016. This led to the categorisation of Guatemala as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview. . The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Bangladesh on a daily basis.

HRV.main:
Croatia is one the route taken by migrants and refugees to reach western Europe. ACAPS reports are available under the Special Reports tab. Our theme page provides provides more information on the topic

In May 2014, Croatia was affected by flooding. For more information, see our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

HTI.main:
Hurricane Matthew, a Category 4 Hurricane, struck Haiti on 4 October, and caused widespread damage, flooding, and displacement. 2,128,700 people, or 12% of Haiti’s population, were affected, including 894,100 children?

In addition 80% of Haiti has been affected by El Niño conditions since the beginning of 2015, and around one million Haitians have been affected by drought. A cholera outbreak has persisted since October 2010.

The country is regularly to natural disasters, including hurricanes, floods, earthquakes, landslides, and droughts. The resilience of the population is extremely low, and the political and economic situation is fragile.

INFORM measures Haiti's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.5/10. Hazard and exposure is at 5.4/10. Vulnerability and lack of coping capacity are at alarming levels, with rates of 6.7/10 and 7.5/10.?

IDN.main: Indonesia is suffering an El Niño-related drought, which has led to a food crisis in 2016. See our Special Reports tab for ACAPS analysis of the crisis.

IND.main: In November 2015, several days of heavy rainfall in Tamil Nadu led to flash flooding. At least 29,000 people were evacuated; Cuddalore district was particularly affected. Go to the Special Reports tab to find our Briefing Note on the crisis.

IRQ.main:
In 2014, Islamic State (IS) took over significant portions of Iraqi territory, triggering mass displacement and severe humanitarian needs. After a military stalemate throughout much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from IS were stepped up in 2016 and are ongoing in 2017, aggravating displacement and humanitarian needs, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors.? Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern.

Iraq now hosts three million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world.? IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).?

INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.7/10 and 7/10 rates.?
IRQ.latest_developments_past:
05/03: Sunni tribal groups and Iraqi soldiers forcibly displaced at least 125 families in Salah al Din, over suspected ties with IS. The families are reportedly being held near Tikrit. Some houses have been demolished.? 

05/03: 4,000 people have been fleeing west Mosul daily, compared to 10,000 weekly during the battle for control of east Mosul. Displacement in the past two weeks has reach 50,000, including 15,000 children.? ?

03/03: Chemical weapons are suspected to have been fired from west to east Mosul, as 15 people were admitted to Erbil exhibiting symptoms consistent with exposure to chemical agents.?

JOR.main:
Registered Syrian refugees alone account for around 10% of Jordan’s population, and estimates of the total number of Syrians in Jordan are much higher than the 655,000 registered by the UNHCR.? There are also significant numbers of refugees from Iraq and Palestine, as well as other countries such as Sudan, Somalia, and Yemen.?? The increase in population has put pressure on local infrastructure and services. Many refugees and vulnerable Jordanians live in substandard shelter, and face food security, WASH, health, education, protection, and livelihood needs. In addition to the refugee population inside Jordan, around 80,000 Syrian refugees live in settlements around the Rukban and Hadalat border crossings between Syria and Jordan, referred to as the berm.?

INFORM measures Jordan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.1/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, however, at 6.1/10.?
JOR.latest_developments_past: 01/03: A number of security incidents including tribal conflicts and threat of terrorism caused delays to aid distributions at the berm.  On some occasions distributions have been cancelled by the Jordanian Armed Forces.?

KEN.main:
Kenya faces recurrent drought, flooding, malnutrition and food insecurity, disease outbreaks, and inter-communal conflict. Food security is deteriorating, with 2.7 million in need of immediate food assistance in January 2017, compared to 1.3 million people in August 2016. Drought conditions have worsened in Eastern, Coast and Northeastern regions, and county governors in these areas have called for urgent intervention. 

Kenya also hosts some one of the largest refugee populations in the world, just above 500,000, with over 300,000 from Somalia. The government plans to close the Dadaab refugee camp complex by March 2017, and return the Somali refugees.

INFORM measures Kenya’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10.?
KEN.latest_developments_past:
02/03:  Three teachers were abducted by Al Shabaab in Dadaab camp. One was later released.

27/02:  Cholera outbreak reported in Lamu county, with seven hospitalised.

23/02: More than 20 schools have been closed due to continued insecurity in Baringo county.

09/02: Closure of Dadaab camp blocked as is unconstitutional.?

KHM.main: Cambodia is facing its worst drought in 50 years, with water shortages being experienced in 18 out of the country's 25 provinces. Visit our Special reports section to read our latest briefing note.

LBN.main:
Lebanon has the highest per capita concentration of refugees worldwide, hosting more than 1.5 million Syrian refugees, as well as large populations of Palestinian refugees and Palestinian refugees from Syria. Tensions between host and refugee populations are increasing due to food price hikes, pressure on health and education systems, housing, employment, and legal documentation issues. Tensions between Lebanese authorities and the Joint Palestinian Security Forces have increased due to alleged infiltrations of armed groups in some camps. 

INFORM measures Lebanon’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.7/10.?

LBR.main:
Humanitarian needs in Liberia spiked in 2014 and 2015, when the Ebola epidemic caused a severe crisis throughout the country.

Liberia's baseline indicators (see Country Profile) provide an insight into the country's vulnerability to crisis.

LBY.main:
Libya’s government is split between three rival centres of power: the Government of National Accord (GNA) and the General National Congress (GNC), based in Tripoli, and the House of Representatives (HoR), based in Tobruk. These governments rely on militias for territorial control: the GNA is supported by a powerful militia coalition from Misrata, while the HoR is allied with the Libyan National Army, led by Khalifa Haftar, a former Gaddafi associate turned opposition figure who returned to Libya during the 2011 uprising. The GNC has lost control of Tripoli since the GNA moved to the city from Tunis in early 2016, but remains associated with some Islamist-leaning militias in the capital. These fight occasionally with groups allied with the GNA.

1.3 million people are in need of some form of humanitarian assisstance as the result of a conflict that has generated shortages of food, fuel, water, medical supplies, and electricity, as well as reduced access to healthcare and public services.? Much of the fighting takes place in urban centres, posing serious security concerns for civilian populations. Humanitarian access is a major concern, since most international NGOs pulled out of the country in 2014.?

INFORM measures Libya's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 8.4/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.?
LBY.latest_developments_past: Since 03/03: BDB forces have attacked the facilities on the oil crescent controlled by the LNA, which has been forced to retreat. There have been conflicting reports as to where positions are currently located.?

LKA.main:
Over 350,000 peopl have been affected by flooding – 200,000 have been evacuated to temporary shelters.

Click on "Special Reports" to read our latest briefing note on floods in Sri Lanka.

LSO.main: Lesotho is experiencing severe drought due to below-average rainfall and high temperatures during the 2015/2016 El Niño. The weakening rand and increased food prices are aggravating the humanitarian crisis.  Around one-quarter of the population is severely food insecure and half the rural population is at risk of livelihood and food insecurity until April 2017.?  All districts are in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) conditions and many people and services have only limited access to water.? Seasonal short rains from October to December 2016 somewhat eased drought conditions and created employment opportunities across the country.  INFORM measures Lesotho's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 at 4.2/10. Vulnerability and coping capacity rates are at 5.2/10 and 6.7/10, respectively.
LSO.latest_developments_upcoming: FEWSNET predicts Lesotho will not have external food assistance needs in July 2017.

MDG.main:
Severe drought conditions have led to a third consecutive year of below-average food production, particularly in the south. Tsihombe, Ambovombe, and Bekily districts in Androy region are most affected: poor households are facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food security outcomes.

From 3 to 23 January, rains and flooding have affected over 12,000 people and damaged 2,000 houses in the Toliara region.? 

INFORM measures Madagascar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 5/10, compared to 4.9/10 in 2016. Madagascar's vulnerability is of concern, at 4.1/10.? ?
MDG.latest_developments_past: 07-09/03: Tropical Cyclone Enawo,  equivalent to a Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson scale, made landfall over Antalaha district on 7 March. Over 22,000 people have been affected, including 10,000 displaced in Analanjirofo region. Five people have been killed, and six others injured.?
MDG.latest_developments_upcoming:
A below-average harvest of staple food cassava and sweet potato in July and August is expected. Food stocks will deplete earlier than usual and food access is expected to be significantly constrained by November 2016.

Food insecurity in 2017, in terms of magnitude and severity, is expected to increase as food insecure areas of the south approach the peak of the 2016/17 lean season between January and March 2017.

MKD.main: FYR Macedonia is on the route to western Europe for hundreds of thousands of people who are seeking asylum. ACAPS reports on the humanitarian situation among people in transit can be found under the Special Reports tab.

MLI.main:
Insecurity persists in northern and central Mali. Tension between two of the signatories of the 2015 peace deal, the Azawad Movement Coalition (CMA) and the Groupe Autodéfense Touareg Imghad et Alliés (GATIA), periodically flare into conflict.  Attacks by Islamist armed groups, who are not part of the peace agreement, increased in 2016. 

Overall, a lack of access to basic social services and the low capacity of public administration drives humanitarian needs. While IDPs and refugees have slowly been returning home since 2013, over 44,000 people remain internally displaced as of October 2016 and around 139,000 refugees are still in neighbouring countries as of January 2017. ?

INFORM measures Mali's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels, at 6.2/10, 6.8/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.?
MLI.latest_developments_past:
06/03: Peace authorities could not be established in Timbuktu as scheduled, because a CMA faction is physically blocking them. ?

02/03: More than 9,000 people were displaced due to intercommunal violence - mainly from Macina circle of Segou region – throughout Mali in February 2017. ?

02/03: Ansar Dine, al Mourabitoun, Ansar Dine and al Qaeda in the Islamist Maghreb (AQIM) have created a new coalition, called Jamaat Nasr al Islam wa al mouminin (Group for the Victory of Islam and Fidels). This is likely to negatively impact stability throughout Mali.  ?
MLI.latest_developments_upcoming: 01/2017: Joint patrols between armed groups and Malian State authorities are due to start soon in Gao.

MMR.main:
Protracted armed conflict between ethnic groups and the government means over 525,500 people are in continued need of assistance, including over 123,300 people in Kachin and Shan states, and 402,000 people in Rakhine state.?? Access to populations in need is constrained.? Several groups are still in armed conflict with the government, predominantly in Kachin, Shan, and Rakhine states.

In Rakhine state, discrimination against the Rohingya Muslim minority has caused protracted displacement. IDPs in Rakhine have limited access to services as they are confined to camps. Since October 2016, tensions between the Rohingya and the Myanmar Army have escalated and access has deteriorated further.?

INFORM measures Myanmar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.7/10. Hazard and exposure, as well as lack of coping capacity, and vulnerability are at 7.5/10, 6/10 and 6.6/10 respectively.?
MMR.latest_developments_past: 06/03: 30 people have been killed, including at least five civilians, in clashes between the Myanmar army and the Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army (MNDAA) in the Kokang region of northeastern Shan state. 20,000 are thought to have fled to China.??

MNG.main: The dzud - a phenomenon characterised by harsh winter conditions - put around 400,000 people in the northern and western Mongolia at risk of losing livestock and livelihoods in early 2016. See our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

MOZ.main:
As a result of El Niño-related drought in southern provinces, 2.1 million people are are acutely food insecure.? The number of food insecure is likely to further increase between October 2016 and March 2017, when the lean season reaches its peak. There are acute water shortages in southern Mozambique, despite heavy rains and floods in January 2017 which affected 79,000 people.?

In October 2015, tensions between Renamo and Frelimo erupted into armed clashes. Central Mozambique is most affected. A two-month truce was declared at the beginning of January, after mediators left the country in December.?? There are currently 15,000 IDPS in the country.?About 3,500 Mozambicans were reported in Malawi as of December.?Politically motivated killings have been on the rise in 2016 and have been aimed especially at Renamo members.?

INFORM measures Mozambique’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6/10. Mozambique’s lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 6.7/10.?
MOZ.latest_developments_past: 06/03: In Sofala province, floods at the beginning of March affected 5,100 households in 20 villages in Machanga district, which had already been hit in January. Power to Machanga city was cut when an electricity pylon fell. The road from the main north–south highway to Machanga town, Sofala province, has been cut in two points. Several roads in the Limpopo Valley have also been cut, notably the Guijá–Chinhacanine, Guijá–Chibuto, and Chissano–Chibuto roads.??
MOZ.latest_developments_upcoming: After reaching 2.3 million at the end of March 2017, the number of people facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes will drop significantly as the majority of households will be benefitting from harvests.?

MRT.main:
Mauritania has longstanding food security challenges, and severe levels of food insecurity are currently reported in pockets of the country (IPC Phases 3–5). This has contributed to 120,000 cases of malnutrition as of December 2017, most of which are in the south and eastern parts of the country.?

The number of refugees grew towards the end of 2016 as people fled violence in Mali, but has slowed in early 2017.?

INFORM measures Mauritania's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 at 5.7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 7/10. ?

MWI.main:
Drought has led to the most severe food crisis Malawi has faced in a decade: 6.5 million people (40% of the population) are expected to be food insecure in the November-March lean season. Food prices continue to rise as more households have to purchase food to meet their needs. Typhoid and cholera cases are reported across the country.

INFORM measures Malawi’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.8/10. Malawi’s lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 6.4/10 as well as vulnerability at 6.3/10.?
MWI.latest_developments_upcoming: Between December and January, food security outcomes were expected to improve to Stressed (IPC Phase 2), in the presence of humanitarian assistance. These improved outcomes are expected to continue in February and March, during the peak lean season. In the absence of humanitarian assistance, areas in central and southern Malawi would experience Crisis (IPC Phase 3) and Emergency (IPC Phase 4) outcomes.?

NAM.main:
Namibia has been struggling with the El Niño-related drought since the beginning of 2015. Significant food shortages and lack of rain continued throughout 2016. Harvests are expected to be 18% better than 2015, but production is still 29% lower than the five-year average. Coupled with high import prices and the depreciation of Namibia’s currency, this means cereal prices were higher in 2016 than 2015.

The 2017 lean season, which runs from January-March, is expected to be worse than previous years, with 720,000 people facing food insecurity. As of January, 700,000 people rely of food assistance provided by the government.

INFORM measures Namibia’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 3.7/10.?
NAM.latest_developments_past: 4-5/03: Eight people drowned due to floods across the country. Several schools were closed as they were surrounded by water. ??

NER.main:
Drought, floods, and epidemics in Niger frequently drive food security, nutrition, and health crises. Compounding this situation, and despite regional military efforts, Boko Haram (BH) attacks impact civilian populations along the Komadougou Yobe River and the shores of Lake Chad. Niger is also a transit country for migrants heading towards Europe. Some of them become stranded around Agadez and need protection assistance. ?

As of 19 November, 1.9 million people are in need in Niger, including 340,000 people in Diffa region.?

Between June and September, 123,000 have been affected by rainfall-induced flooding in Niger.?

INFORM measures Niger's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 7.3/10, up from 5.6/10 in 2016. Niger's lack of coping capacity, measured at 7.8/10 is of particular concern.?
NER.latest_developments_past:
06/03: Clashes between the army of Niger and an Islamic group in Wanzarbé and Yatakala localities in Tilaberi region resulted in five deaths.?

04/03: A state of emergency was enforced in seven departments within Tilaberi and Tahoua regions - bordering Mali, due to repeated attacks by Islamist groups.?

NGA.main:
Violence in the northeast has caused massive displacement and at the same time restricted movement: it has disrupted food supplies, seriously hindered access to basic services, and limited agricultural activities. As of January 2017, it is estimated that 14 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 8.5 million of whom are in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe states. Bauchi (2.8 million people), Gombe (1.4 million), and Taraba (1.3 million) also host high numbers of people in need. ?

In seven years of conflict, over 20,000 people have been killed in Boko Haram-related incidents. People affected by violence in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe, and neighbouring Bauchi, Taraba, and Gombe states are in urgent need of food, access to health services, protection, and education. Since February 2016, as humanitarian access is increasing, extreme food insecurity and malnutrition conditions have been revealed in Borno state.

INFORM measures Nigeria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster as 'high', 6.3/10, and its coping capacity index is 6.6/10. ?
NGA.latest_developments_past:
06/03: The following LGAs have reported above emergency threshold levels of GAM (15%) in their last nutrition assessments. In Borno: Bayo (15.6%, October 2016), Konduga (15.2%, October), Kusar (18.4%, October), Kwaya Magumeri (29.9%, November), Ngala (23%, October) Rann (16%, January), Shani (16.6%, October). In Yobe: Geidam (16.8% in December) and Yunusaru (39.4%, December). ?

01/03: 7,000 people were displaced between 25 February and 1 March from renewed BH attacks in Chibok, Borno state. ? 

01/03: The first case of Lassa Fever was confirmed in Zabarmari village of Jere LGA, Borno state. This follows reports on 24 February that four people were killed in Alkaleri and Ganjuwa LGAs of Bauchi state.  ? ?
NGA.latest_developments_upcoming: Cholera and meningitis epidemics are expected with the onset of the rainy season, set to begin in April. ?

NIC.main: In 2015, 500,000 people in the Central American “Dry Corridor”, covering El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua, were estimated to be facing severe food insecurity. An El Niño-related dry spell brought a second consecutive year of crop losses. See our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

NPL.main:
On 25 April 2015, at 11:41 local time, an earthquake with of 7.8 magnitude hit Nepal. Its epicentre was 77km northwest of Kathmandu, and 68km east of Pokhara. More than 8,600 people died, 2.8 million were displaced, and in all more than 5 million people were affected by the disaster.

ACAPS supported the reporting of the humanitarian impact of the reponse. Weekly bulletins, thematic reports and district profiles were released and can be found here. Earlier and supplementary ACAPS reports can be found in the Special Reports tab.

PAK.main:
Around 3.2 million people are in need of humanitarian aid in Pakistan.? The security situation remains volatile due to militant attacks in urban centres and military operations against the Taliban in the tribal areas. Around 476,000 people remain displaced within Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and FATA.? Additionally around 1.35 million registered and around 1.1 million undocumented Afghans are living in Pakistan.? ?The needs of IDPs and Afghan refugees in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are of particular concern. 

INFORM measures Pakistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.6/10. Pakistan’s exposure to hazards is of particular concern, at 9/10.?
PAK.latest_developments_past: 07/03: Pakistan temporarily reopened two border crossings with Afghanistan, Torkham and Chaman, which had been closed for three weeks. However, Pakistani authorities are planning to close them again on 9 March.?

PHL.main: The Philippines is at high risk of natural disasters. See the Special Reports tab for ACAPS analysis of recent cyclones and food security issues.

PNG.main:
Prolonged drought has severely affected the food security of 1.5 million people across the country in 2016; 1.3 million were food insecure, including 180,000 people were facing extreme food shortages in Western, Hela, Enga, and Milne Bay provinces. Food production was affected by both drought and August frost in the Highlands, and water shortages continue to have an impact on WASH and education. Deaths related to diseases and starvation have been reported, but no official number is available.

The 2015–16 El Niño reached its peak towards the end of 2015 but the impacts on people and their livelihoods remain critical. It is estimated to have affected 2.52 million people in July but as of October the WFP began to cease food handouts due to observable recovery in drought-affected areas. ? ?

Storms and flooding are most likely to hit Papua New Guinea from December until March. ?

INFORM measures PNG's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster is of high concern , at 5.8/10, as well as PNG's vulnerability, 5.7/10. ?

PRK.main:
Humanitarian access remains extremely limited in DPRK, and very little information is available on the humanitarian situation. 15 million people, or 60% of the population, is estimated to be food insecure and the country is highly vulnerable to shortages in food production. ? DPRK is disaster-prone, regularly experiencing intense rain, floods, and droughts.

Typhoon Lionrock, which struck the north of the country on 31 August, caused widespread destruction and displaced over 100,000 people. ?

INFORM measures DPRK's risk index as 5.6/10. The country also has poor coping capacity, with an estimated lack of coping capacity index of 6.9/10.  ?
PRK.latest_developments_past: 28/02: 15 million people in DPRK are considered food insecure, 3.7 million do not have access to essential health services and 1.7 million children are at risk of deadly childhood diseases. ?

PSE.main:
Ensuring the delivery of essential services including healthcare, food, water, and electricity remain of concern across the Gaza strip and the West Bank due to access restrictions imposed by Israel and neighbouring countries. Needs are particularly acute in Gaza, where around 65,000 Palestinians remain displaced from the 50-day war in 2014. The ongoing blockade continues to severely restrict the delivery of services and the movement of people and goods.

INFORM measures Palestine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be at 4.8/10, down from 6.1/10 in 2016. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.3/10.?

RWA.main: Rwanda is impacted by the crisis in Burundi, as it hosts refugees fleeing violence. See the Special Reports tab for more information.

SDN.main:
Protracted insurgencies are being waged by armed groups across Darfur, and persistent conflict situations in South Kordofan and Blue Nile cause high levels of insecurity. Darfur has been the scene of conflict for over a decade, while violence in Blue Nile and South Kordofan increased significantly after South Sudan gained independence in 2011.

Humanitarian access to conflict zones is severely restricted and remains so despite efforts of the AU and UN to broker a peace agreement and ensure increased humanitarian access.

Violence, food insecurity, malnutrition, and lack of access to basic services have caused large-scale internal displacement.

Most recent floods occurred between June and September.

According to INFORM, Sudan is at high risk of being overwhelmed by humanitarian crises and disasters (7/10). Hazard, vulnerability, and a lack of coping capacity are at alarming rates of 7.4/10, 6.6/10, and 7/10.  ?
SDN.latest_developments_past:
05/03: 2,000 IDP families from Jebel Marra currently in Sina, South Darfur, need medicines, food, shelter and NFIs.?

27/02: About 65 asylum seekers from Ethiopia and Eritrea were lashed 40 times on their backs and the back of their legs with leather whips as a formal punishment protesting a huge rise in the cost of their temporary permits.?

SEN.main:
Livelihoods have been affected by both floods and rainfall deficits in northern and western Senegal. Floods between July and September directly affected up to 20,000 people, destroying many agricultural stocks and threatening livelihoods. 

Food security crises are recurrent in Senegal because of drought and floods as indicated by the country’s score of 5.1 on the INFORM index, a rise from 4.3 in the previous yearly index. ? ?
SEN.latest_developments_upcoming: 03/2017: Food insecurity is expected to worsen for the poor households in Fatick, Dakar, Saint Louis, Matam and Louga regions. This is largely due to flooding in July and August that caused crop deterioration. ?

SLE.main: Sierra Leone was the subject of a number of ACAPS reports covering the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, see the Special Reports tab. Baseline data can be found in the Country Profile.

SLV.main:
INFORM measures El Salvador's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 3.5/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 4.7/10.?

The country is recovering from drought since 2015, and was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since mid-December. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor El Salvador on a weekly basis, due to its gang violence and underlying vulnerability.

SOM.main: Al Shabaab’s insurgency, coupled with interclan fighting and a severe El Niño-induced drought, has created large-scale displacement and made basic services almost inaccessible for an estimated 6 million Somalis. The drought is causing significant loss of livelihoods across the country, and widespread displacement. Famine is possible in 2017 if humanitarian assistance is inadequate. Humanitarian access remains extremely limited outside of Somaliland: Lower and Middle Juba regions are particularly inaccessible. The government's control is essentially limited to Mogadishu and surrounding areas, although Al Shabaab attacks in the city persist. Widespread corruption, elections (September 2016-February 2017) and continued insecurity have led to limited national and international response to the ongoing drought, which has spread to new areas of south central Somalia, Puntland, and Somaliland. The INFORM index score for risk of humanitarian catastrophe ranks Somalia at 9.2 out of 10, the highest of any country.
SOM.latest_developments_past:
01-03/03: 110 killed in Baay due to cholera and hunger related causes

01/03: Water prices in Garsobore, Gedo have increased 16 times from the start of the drought

13/02-05/03: 194 cases of cholera a day, compared to less than 100 in 2017 up to 13 February.

February: At least 102,000 displaced by drought in February alone.

SRB.main:
A cold wave hit Serbia in January 2017. ACAPS short note can be found here.

Serbia is on the route for refugees and migrants heading to western Europe. ACAPS produced a number of Briefing Notes on the situation as part of a project in 2015–2016.

A report on heavy flooding in the Balkan countries in May 2014 is also available here.

SSD.main:
Since July 2016 there has been a surge in conflict across the country including in previously less affected areas of Central and Eastern Equatoria. The current situation in these regions is volatile, and there are a large number of displaced people. Food insecurity and malnutrition rates are unprecedented, and insecurity is hampering the delivery of assistance. The UN reports widespread violation of human rights and targeted violence against civilians.

Violence spread across eastern and northern South Sudan in December 2013 after President Kiir accused Vice President Riek Machar of plotting a coup. A ceasefire was agreed in August 2015, and a transitional government set up in April 2016 but fighting continues.

INFORM measures South Sudan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be extremely high, at 8.8/10, an increase from 8.3/10 in 2016. South Sudan's vulnerability is measured at 9/10.?
SSD.latest_developments_past:
05/03: The South Sudanese government ordered humanitarian organisations to leave Mayendit county in Unity ahead of a military operation against the opposition. This is of particular concern as famine was declared in this area in mid-February. ?
 
04/03: Over 5,000 people were displaced from Uror county in Jonglei towards the south east of Upper Nile due to clashes between government and opposition forces. Shortages of food, water and medicines are reported. ?

SVN.main: Slovenia is on the route through the Balkans for people seeking asylum in western Europe. ACAPS reports on the humanitarian situation for migrants and refugees in transit can be found under the Special Reports tab.

SWZ.main:
Poor and erratic rainfall in Swaziland are a result of El Niño and date back to 2014. The country experienced significant reductions in crop production in 2016, a situation that will worsen food security in 2017. 492,454 people require food assistance.?For most of 2016 the five major rivers were flowing below critical environmental sustainability levels. Lubombo and Shiselweni, as well as pockets of Hhohho and Manzani were the worst affected.?

The government of Swaziland declared a national drought disaster in February 2016. The situation is worse than during the 1992 drought.

INFORM evaluates Swaziland's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be moderate at 3.1/10. Swaziland's lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 5.6/10.
SWZ.latest_developments_upcoming: Rainfall forecasts for the 2016/17 main summer cropping season (October-June) indicate an enhanced chance for normal to above-average rainfall conditions.?

SYR.main:
14.9 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Syria, including 6.3 million IDPs.

Conflict has killed over 310,000 people, including 86,000 civilians, and caused large-scale displacement. Protection concerns are widespread. WASH and access to food are high priorities, as well as access to health services. Humanitarian needs in areas under prolonged and ongoing siege are particularly high as access is obstructed.

Clashes are ongoing in Dara, ar Raqqa, Homs, Deir-ez-Zor city, and Hama. After more than a month of decreased clashes between parties involved in the ceasefire, fighting has started again in mid-February between the SAA and opposition armed groups, including the FSA. The Turkish army recently increased activity in Aleppo governorate, targeting both Islamic State and the Kurdish YPG. 

INFORM measures Syria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. The intensity of highly violent conflict in the country is of particular concern . ?
SYR.latest_developments_past:
06/03: 121 suspected cases of measles in Damascus and Rural Damascus in the first two months of 2017 – up from 50 in 2015 and 2016 combined. Malnutrition rates are high in Rural Damascus due to the besiegement of many areas, making the effects of measles on the affected people harsher. ?

05/03: 66,000 people in and around al Bab have been displaced since November 2016 due to clashes. ?

03/03: The fourth round of Geneva talks ended. The parties have agreed on an agenda to be discussed in the next Geneva talks. ?

02/03: Thousands in Damuyr (Rural Damascus) have been displaced by heavy floods. There are significant hygiene concerns for the population in the area as the overflow is filled with dirt and debris. ?

01/03: 2,850 people were killed by the conflict in February 2017 – up from 2,000 in January. ??

TCD.main:
Over 4.7 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Chad, including more than 1 million expected to be severely food insecure across the country in June.  The country faces security threats on its periphery, most notably from Boko Haram (BH) since February 2015 in Lac region. Attacks have targeted both military operations and civilians, driving people from their homes. Around 130,000 people are displaced in Lac region. Nigerian refugees have been crossing into Chad since 2014, further adding to large refugee populations from Sudan in the east, and Central African Republic in the south.

Underlying vulnerability and food insecurity is high, particularly in the Sahelian zone to the north of the country.

INFORM measures Chad's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 7.76/10, up from 6 in 2016. Hazard and exposureVulnerability as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.2.4/10 and 8.99/10.? ?
TCD.latest_developments_past:
28/02: 69 students have been sentenced to one month in prison following clashes with police during a ministerial visit in a campus. Student have been denouncing austerity measures which targeted the education sector for several months now.?

23-24/02: Civil servants’ unions announced they could resume strikes on 6 March, as the government has not met their demands of increasing the wages. Strikes were suspended on mid-January to allow government to meets the demands, but since then, it has announced new austerity measures.??

TJK.main:
715,000 people are in need of food assistance in rural central and eastern parts of the country. Around 43% of Tajik’s GDP is generated through remittances, mostly from Russia. The deteriorating economic situation in Russia and restrictions on the migrant labour market have affected Tajik purchasing power by reducing the frequency and volume of remittances, used by many households to buy food. In addition, Tajikistan relies on food imports to cover needs for cereals, and its weak currency means prices are high.

INFORM measures Tajikistan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium at 4.4/10.?

TLS.main: The drought induced by El Niño is reported on in an ACAPS Briefing Note of April 2016. Analysis of the country's preparedness is also available under the Special Reports tab.

TUR.main:
Turkey hosts over 2.8 million Syrian refugees, who are  in need of food and livelihood support, and shelter assistance.

Tensions between government forces and Kurdish separatists escalated in July 2015.  Clashes and bomb attacks occur mostly in the southeast, but occasionally in Istanbul and Ankara. Curfews limit access to affected areas, and hundreds of thousands of people have been internally displaced. Widespread destruction of shelter has been reported.

Tens of thousands of people have been arrested, detained, or dismissed since a failed coup in July 2016. Media freedom and the independence of the judiciary are of concern. The crackdown on pro-Kurdish political parties has escalated. 

INFORM measures Turkey's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 5.0/10. Hazard and exposure is of particular concern, at a 7.8/10 rate.?
TUR.latest_developments_past:
24/02: In Bitlis province, fighting between Turkish police and PKK resulted in the death of ten PKK fighters.?

24/02: Curfews were expanded to new areas in the southeastern provinces Diyarbakir and Mardin.?

21/02: One pro-Kurdish HDP MP lost her seat at the Turkish parliament, as she was convicted on terrorism charges.?
TUR.latest_developments_upcoming: 16/04: Referendum on constitutional changes to move from a parliamentary to an executive presidential system.?

UGA.main:
Uganda currently hosts over  898,000 refugees and asylum seekers from neighbouring countries.? Renewed insecurity in some of these countries, such as South Sudan, DRC and Burundi, brought an increase in arrival rates as of the end of 2015, putting Ugandan services under strain.?

INFORM measures Uganda's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of concern, at 6.9/10. ?
UGA.latest_developments_past: 16/02: Up to 4,000 South Sudanese were crossing into Uganda daily, the highest rate since the escalation  of refugees on July 2016. Most are processed at Palorinya camp in Moyo district, where food, water, shelter, toilets, and medicine is scarce.?

UKR.main:
Eastern Ukraine has been in a humanitarian crisis since March 2014, when armed conflict erupted between separatists and Ukrainian armed forces. Separatists now control most of eastern Donetsk region, and a small area of southern Luhansk region. 3.8 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance and more than 2.8 million have been displaced. Protection and health are of particular concern in conflict areas, particularly as a large number of older people are affected. Humanitarian access is constrained: virtually all international aid organisations (all in Donestk) have been banned from non-government areas. ? However, in September 2016 UNHCR’s license to operate in Donetsk and surrounding areas was renewed. ?

INFORM measures Ukraine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.3/10. Hazard exposure rating is also very high at 7/10.?
UKR.latest_developments_past:
03/03: Following the announcement threatening to seize control of assets in the area by de facto authorities in response to the railway blockade, 40 enterprises in Donetsk Non-Government Controlled Areas (NGCA) were ‘nationalised’. Many offices were occupied by armed groups, including a communications company, resulting in the suspension of communications services to 200,000 people in NGCA. ?

02/03: The largest provider of humanitarian aid in the separatist held area of eastern Ukraine, where most international aid agencies do not have access, has suspended all services after separatist authorities closed its entire network of distribution points. ??

28/02:  Separatist in eastern Ukraine threatened to take control of Ukraine-run businesses in separatist-held territory if the Kiev government does not take action to end a rail blockade that has halted the movement of coal supplies from the east in to the rest of the country. Seizing assets would be a clear violation of the already weak Minsk II peace agreement. ?

VEN.main: By February 2016, Venezuela had reported over 4,500 confirmed cases of Zika virus. However, unofficial estimates were thought to be as high as 400,000. ACAPS Briefing Note on the Zika outbreak across Latin America and the Caribbean can be found under the Special Reports tab.

YEM.main:
18.8 million people are in need of humanitarian aid, including 10.3 million people in acute need, after fighting escalated in March 2015.? 

An armed advance on the capital in September 2014 by Houthis from the north triggered a civil war throughout the country. A coalition led by Saudi Arabia is supporting the Yemeni government with airstrikes. Activities by southern secessionists Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Islamic State (IS) compound the security and political challenges.?

The humanitarian situation is further exacerbated by Yemen’s failing economy. The Central Bank in Yemen is near collapse, putting food imports at risk.?

The Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) declared Yemen a Level 3 emergency in July 2015. INFORM measures Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at a very high level of 7.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels: 8.2/10, 7.9/10 and 7.8/10 respectively.?
YEM.latest_developments_past:
06/03: In Taiz, 37 of the city’s 40 hospitals and medical centres have been forced to close due to fighting and lack of medical supplies. More than 350,000 people are in need of urgent medical aid. ? 

06/03: Four civilians have been killed and nearly a dozen injured in a new wave of arial attacks by the Saudi-led coalition in Amran. Yemen’s Legal Centre for Rights and Development now estimates the civilian death toll of the conflict at 12,041. ?

03/03: According to the Emergency Food and Nutrition Assessment over 17 million people in Yemen are food insecure, which has increased by 3 million people since the last IPC analysis in June 2016. 7.3 million people are estimated to be in need of emergency food assistance. ?

02/03: The UN has verified the recruitment of 1,476 child soldiers, all boys, between 26 March 2015 and 31 January 2017. ?

02/03: Humanitarian ships and supplies have been forced to redirect, putting the food market at greater risk. This situation, in addition to price increases, a fuel shortage, and public salary crisis, is causing an emergency food security situation. ?

ZMB.main:
As a result of El Niño-related drought in southern provinces, almost one million people are food insecure in Zambia.? The worst affected provinces are Southern, Western, Eastern and Lusaka. Current food prices are 66% above the five-year average. The food security situation is, however, likely to improve from March to May, thanks to the upcoming green harvests.?

INFORM measures Zambia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.1/10. Lack of coping capacity and vulnerability of particular concern at 6.1/10 and 5.3/10, respectively.
ZMB.latest_developments_past: 05/03: Heavy rains in Southern province are affecting maize fields and property for more than 500 families. In Copperbelt province, slum areas have been affected by floods as a result of a poor drainage system. 43 houses have been damaged.?

ZWE.main:
Zimbabwe has experienced its driest rainy season in 35 years. The El Niño-induced drought has resulted in a severe and ongoing food security crisis. ? This has been exacerbated by a severe economic crisis.

Popular discontent grew throughout 2016, with increasing anti-government protests. Authorities responded with violent crackdowns. Demonstrations have persisted despite police violence.  ??? 

INFORM measures Zimbabwe’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 5.8/10.?
ZWE.latest_developments_past: 07/03: 2,000 people are reported displaced due to the effects of cyclone Dineo. This number of displaced is up from 850 reported in the previous week. Among reports of casualties and infrastructure damage, the government has declared a national disaster. Matabelaland North is the hardest-hit province.??
